text:
Tomcat 4.0 stops configuring listeners if one of the listeners in the list 
isn't present, should it carry on configuring the rest of the listeners it 
finds? The spec is silent on this and it seems odd that if somebody (maybe 
accidently) deletes a listener class all other following listeners are not 
configured (any listener preceeding the missing listener would already have 
been initialised).
creator: kevinj@develop.com
craig.mcclanahan@sun.com
text:
I've modified the Context startup so that any significant error (including
failures in initializing Listeners or Filters) will leave the application
unavailable afterwards.  This bug report is marked RESOLVED/REMIND because the
expert group might come to a different conclusion about whether Listener/Filter 
startup problems should be fatal to the entire app or not.

Allowing an application to become available even though there was a problem
initializing a listener (or filter) would be a significant security risk -- for
example, an application that uses these techniques to provide application
managed authentication and access control would be exposed to unauthenticated
use if the listener or filter implementing this feature could not be started
successfully.  Therefore, no changes will be made and I'm going to close this
bug report.
